normalised: What are some important things to know about Tax Law in India?

unnormalised: What are some important things to know about Tax Law in India?
normalised: Namaste! Understanding Tax Law in India can seem daunting, but it is crucial for every responsible citizen and business owner. Let us break down some key aspects to help you navigate this complex landscape.

unnormalised: Namaste! Understanding Tax Law in India can seem daunting, but it's crucial for every responsible citizen and business owner. Let's break down some key aspects to help you navigate this complex landscape.
normalised: Firstly, the Income Tax Act, one thousand nine hundred and sixty one is the bedrock. It lays down the rules for taxing income earned in India. This includes salary, business profits, capital gains (like selling property or shares), and income from other sources. For example, if you sell a flat you inherited in Mumbai for rupee eighty lakh and it was valued at rupee fifty lakh when you inherited it, the rupee thirty lakh difference is a capital gain that will be taxed (subject to certain deductions and exemptions). Keep in mind Section fifty four provides an exemption under some conditions like investing in another house.

unnormalised: Firstly, the Income Tax Act, 1961 is the bedrock. It lays down the rules for taxing income earned in India. This includes salary, business profits, capital gains (like selling property or shares), and income from other sources. For example, if you sell a flat you inherited in Mumbai for Rs. 80,00,000 and it was valued at Rs. 50,00,000 when you inherited it, the Rs. 30,00,000 difference is a capital gain that will be taxed (subject to certain deductions and exemptions). Keep in mind Sec 54 provides an exemption under some conditions like investing in another house.
normalised: Secondly, understand the concept of different assessment years (A-Y) and financial years (F-Y). F-Y two thousand twenty three to two thousand twenty four refers to the period from first april two thousand twenty three to thirty first march two thousand twenty four. A-Y two thousand twenty four to two thousand twenty five is the year in which you file your taxes for the income earned during F-Y two thousand twenty three to two thousand twenty four. The last date to file your I-T-R (Income Tax Return) is usually july thirty first, but often extends to august thirty first.

unnormalised: Secondly, understand the concept of different assessment years (AY) and financial years (FY). FY 2023-24 refers to the period from 01/04/2023 to 31/03/2024. AY 2024-25 is the year in which you file your taxes for the income earned during FY 2023-24. The last date to file your ITR (Income Tax Return) is usually July 31st, but often extends to Aug 31st.
normalised: Thirdly, T-D-S (Tax Deducted at Source) is a significant factor. If your income crosses a certain threshold, like rupee two lakh and fifty thousand per annum, your employer or the entity paying you will deduct tax at source and deposit it with the government. You can claim credit for this T-D-S while filing your I-T-R. Remember to check Form twenty six A-S to see all T-D-S deductions reflected against your P-A-N.

unnormalised: Thirdly, TDS (Tax Deducted at Source) is a significant factor. If your income crosses a certain threshold, like Rs. 2,50,000 p.a., your employer or the entity paying you will deduct tax at source and deposit it with the government. You can claim credit for this TDS while filing your ITR. Remember to check Form 26AS to see all TDS deductions reflected against your PAN.
normalised: Fourth, G-S-T (Goods and Services Tax) is a comprehensive indirect tax levied on the supply of goods and services. It has replaced many earlier indirect taxes like excise duty, service tax, and V-A-T. Businesses with a turnover exceeding rupee twenty lakh (rupee ten lakh for some special category states) are required to register for G-S-T. G-S-T rates vary, with some essential items taxed at zero percent and luxury goods at twenty eight percent. The registration process happens via gst.gov.in.

unnormalised: Fourth, GST (Goods and Services Tax) is a comprehensive indirect tax levied on the supply of goods and services. It has replaced many earlier indirect taxes like excise duty, service tax, and VAT. Businesses with a turnover exceeding Rs. 20 lakh (Rs. 10 lakh for some special category states) are required to register for GST. GST rates vary, with some essential items taxed at 0% and luxury goods at 28%. The registration process happens via gst.gov.in.
normalised: Fifth, don't forget the importance of tax planning! You can reduce your tax liability through various deductions under Section eighty C, eighty D, eighty G, etcetera. For example, investments in P-P-F (Public Provident Fund), E-L-S-S (Equity Linked Savings Scheme), and insurance premiums qualify for deductions under eighty C, up to a limit of rupee one lakh and fifty thousand. Medical insurance premiums paid for yourself, your spouse, and your dependent children can be claimed under eighty D, up to rupee twenty five thousand (more for senior citizens).

unnormalised: Fifth, don't forget the importance of tax planning! You can reduce your tax liability through various deductions under Section 80C, 80D, 80G, etc. For example, investments in PPF (Public Provident Fund), ELSS (Equity Linked Savings Scheme), and insurance premiums qualify for deductions under 80C, up to a limit of Rs. 1.5 lakh. Medical insurance premiums paid for yourself, your spouse, and your dependent children can be claimed under 80D, up to Rs. 25000 (more for senior citizens).
normalised: Finally, stay updated with the latest amendments and notifications issued by the Income Tax Department and the G-S-T Council. Tax laws are constantly evolving, so it is important to keep yourself informed to avoid any penalties or legal issues. Websites like incometax.gov.in and cbic.gov.in are valuable resources. Consulting a qualified C-A (Chartered Accountant) like Mister R.K. Gupta can also provide personalized guidance.
